messages: f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:15): how do I figure out Pacfic time in IRC I wonder
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (00:16): You could ask out loud in IRC and hope somebody responds who actually knows the answer to your question :-)
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (00:18): (If 4pm PT is 23:00Z then that's about 1.75 hours from now)
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:23): I am wondering what the correct TZ code is
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:23): PDT, at the moment
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:24): iirc
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:24): google and the web know the answers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:24): http://www.google.com/search?q=time+in+san+francisco
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:25): nox:~% TZ=America/Los_Angeles date
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:25): nox:~% TZ=PDT date
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:25): I wonder why TZ=PDT date gives my UTC on my system. bleh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:26): clearly `uname` sucks.
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:27): it works on yours? :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:27): which one?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:27): is using four separate computers right now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:28): with four separate OSes
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:28): `TZ=PDT date`
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:29): last is the debian system?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:30): nope, last one was Darwin
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:30): (specifically, 10.4)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:30): (it was the only one that wasn't running GNU date, too)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:30): so from this we learn that GNU sucks :-P
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:31): and that "PDT" is clearly not the right value of TZ
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:31): eh? what's the correct code?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:31): no idea
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:32): tries to find a machine that actually is in that timezone so he can see what it's TZ is set to
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:32): none of my machines have TZ set
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:32): except one which _is_ in that timezone... it has TZ="UTC+0"
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:33): -8 for Pacific http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_time
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:34): my "datelocal" template in my ion3 config uses 'date +"%R PST"'
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:34): which doesn't help us at all :-)
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:36): man, ion3 is bloatware, check http://www.suckless.org/wiki/dwm
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:38): yeah i only run with like 1/10th of ion3's features
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:38): i don't know what the devs were thinking
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:39): (dwm has much the same problems)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:39): it takes 10 dev for them all to run only a 10th :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:39): (and it doesn't support multihead, which is a blocker for me since my desktop is 2x24")

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:40): lol. "Because dwm is customized through editing its source code, it's pointless to make binary packages of it. This keeps its userbase small and elitist. No novices asking stupid questions."
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:41): but are the Debian packages? :-)
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:41): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: yes, it is packaged :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:41): dwm looks ugly, sheesh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:41): hugs ion3
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:42): strokes dwm
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:43): awesome is dwm with multihead http://awesome.naquadah.org/screenshots/
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:43): ok, what are your thoughts on content adaption?
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:43): have you seen what novarra and openwave do?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:43): (doesn't look anything like what i want my wm to look like, fwiw)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:45): content adaption? you mean like css media queries?
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:45): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: no, like when they sit in the middle and blindly rewrite HTML for crappy mobile UAs
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:46): for e.g. http://natalian.org/archives/2007/10/09/mobile-web-monday/#comment-33580
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:46): i guess it's an acceptable workaround to crappy mobile UAs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:46): seems better to just have decent mobile UAs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:46): if my iPod can have a decent browser that can handle GMail, i don't see why a phone can't
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:47): yes, that's what I push for. better UAs
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:48): fwiw, the moment when I realized that the Maemo platform is for real was when I saw timeless do his Gmail bugmail on the Nokia 770
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:49): greases his new 'ipod touch'
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:49): OpenWave migth have happier users if their offering was an Opera Mini clone
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:50): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: unfortunately their not in the browser market
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (00:50): s/their/they are
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:52): nn
